subsc: Sub-national government administration,Primary education,Tertiary education,Central government administration

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of the project gave mixed
            results, for although the accessibility to primary
            education, and, the achievement of the emergency program
            objective for schools rehabilitation was satisfactory, the
            quality of primary education did not improve, and is
            considered unsatisfactory. Given the post-conflict
            constraints, sustainability remains uncertain. The lessons
            spell out, that even though the project was instrumental in
            transferring resources to, and restructuring of the
            education sector, the complex project design did not take
            into account the weak institutional capabilities following
            the genocide, instead, project objectives should have been
            scheduled to follow technical, and implementation capacity
            levels, once acquired. Although sensible intent, and
            commitment by the Government to restore resources to
            education existed, implementation affected the quality, and
            management activities in the sector. It is suggested that in
            post-conflict situations, where substantial changes occur,
            project restructuring, in agreement with the Government,
            should take place, as well as an assessment of ownership,
            and commitment, followed by an institutional capacity
            assessment, and, performance indicators to measure progress,
            should be redefined. The outcome shows that accessibility
            expansion, at the expense of education quality, is neither
            cost-effective, nor educationally sound.
